column2: Minnie's flat, as the one-floor resident apartments were then being called, was in a part of West Van Buren Street inhabited by families of labourers and clerks, men who had come, and were still coming, with the rush of population pouring in at the rate of 50,000 a year.

column2: To Carrie, the sound of the little bells upon the horse-cars, as they tinkled in and out of hearing, was as pleasing as it was novel. column2: Before following her in her round of seeking, let us look at the sphere in which her future was to lie.

column2: In 1889 Chicago had the peculiar qualifications of growth which made such adventuresome pilgrimages even on the part of young girls plausible.
column3: In eighteen eighty nine Chicago had the peculiar qualifications of growth which made such adventuresome pilgrimages even on the part of young girls plausible.

column2: Its many and growing commercial opportunities gave it widespread fame, which made of it a giant magnet, drawing to itself, from all quarters, the hopeful and the hopeless--those who had their fortune yet to make and those whose fortunes and affairs had reached a disastrous climax elsewhere.
column3: Its many and growing commercial opportunities gave it widespread fame, which made of it a giant magnet, drawing to itself, from all quarters, the hopeful and the hopeless-those who had their fortune yet to make and those whose fortunes and affairs had reached a disastrous climax elsewhere.

column2: It was a city of over 500,000, with the ambition, the daring, the activity of a metropolis of a million.
column3: It was a city of over five hundred thousand, with the ambition, the daring, the activity of a metropolis of a million.

column2: Its streets and houses were already scattered over an area of seventy-five square miles.
column3: Its streets and houses were already scattered over an area of seventy five square miles.

column2: Its population was not so much thriving upon established commerce as upon the industries which prepared for the arrival of others.
column3: Its population was not so much thriving upon established commerce as upon the industries which prepared for the arrival of others.

column2: The sound of the hammer engaged upon the erection of new structures was everywhere heard.
column3: The sound of the hammer engaged upon the erection of new structures was everywhere heard.

column2: Great industries were moving in.
column3: Great industries were moving in.

column2: The huge railroad corporations which had long before recognised the prospects of the place had seized upon vast tracts of land for transfer and shipping purposes.
column3: The huge railroad corporations which had long before recognised the prospects of the place had seized upon vast tracts of land for transfer and shipping purposes.

column2: Street-car lines had been extended far out into the open country in anticipation of rapid growth. The city had laid miles and miles of streets and sewers through regions where, perhaps, one solitary house stood out alone--a pioneer of the populous ways to be.
column3: Street car lines had been extended far out into the open country in anticipation of rapid growth. The city had laid miles and miles of streets and sewers through regions where, perhaps, one solitary house stood out alone-a pioneer of the populous ways to be.

column2: There were regions open to the sweeping winds and rain, which were yet lighted throughout the night with long, blinking lines of gas-lamps, fluttering in the wind.
column3: There were regions open to the sweeping winds and rain, which were yet lighted throughout the night with long, blinking lines of gas lamps, fluttering in the wind.

column2: Narrow board walks extended out, passing here a house, and there a store, at far intervals, eventually ending on the open prairie.
column3: Narrow board walks extended out, passing here a house, and there a store, at far intervals, eventually ending on the open prairie.

column2: In the central portion was the vast wholesale and shopping district, to which the uninformed seeker for work usually drifted.
column3: In the central portion was the vast wholesale and shopping district, to which the uninformed seeker for work usually drifted.

column2: It was a characteristic of Chicago then, and one not generally shared by other cities, that individual firms of any pretension occupied individual buildings.

column2: The presence of ample ground made this possible.

column2: It gave an imposing appearance to most of the wholesale houses, whose offices were upon the ground floor and in plain view of the street.
column3: It gave an imposing appearance to most of the wholesale houses, whose offices were upon the ground floor and in plain view of the street.

column2: The large plates of window glass, now so common, were then rapidly coming into use, and gave to the ground floor offices a distinguished and prosperous look. column3: Polished brass or nickel signs at the square stone entrances announced the firm and the nature of the business in rather neat and reserved terms.

column2: The entire metropolitan centre possessed a high and mighty air calculated to overawe and abash the common applicant, and to make the gulf between poverty and success seem both wide and deep.
column3: The entire metropolitan centre possessed a high and mighty air calculated to overawe and abash the common applicant, and to make the gulf between poverty and success seem both wide and deep.

column2: Into this important commercial region the timid Carrie went.

column2: She walked east along Van Buren Street through a region of lessening importance, until it deteriorated into a mass of shanties and coal-yards, and finally verged upon the river.
column3: She walked east along Van Buren Street through a region of lessening importance, until it deteriorated into a mass of shanties and coal yards, and finally verged upon the river.

column2: She walked bravely forward, led by an honest desire to find employment and delayed at every step by the interest of the unfolding scene, and a sense of helplessness amid so much evidence of power and force which she did not understand.
column3: She walked bravely forward, led by an honest desire to find employment and delayed at every step by the interest of the unfolding scene, and a sense of helplessness amid so much evidence of power and force which she did not understand.

column2: These vast buildings, what were they?

column2: These strange energies and huge interests, for what purposes were they there?

column2: She could have understood the meaning of a little stone-cutter's yard at Columbia City, carving little pieces of marble for individual use, but when the yards of some huge stone corporation came into view, filled with spur tracks and flat cars, transpierced by docks from the river and traversed overhead by immense trundling cranes of wood and steel, it lost all significance in her little world.

column2: She could only think of people connected with them as counting money, dressing magnificently, and riding in carriages.

column2: It was all wonderful, all vast, all far removed, and she sank in spirit inwardly and fluttered feebly at the heart as she thought of entering any one of these mighty concerns and asking for something to do--something that she could do--anything.
